textSrc: When someone mentions Cuba,
what do you think about?
Classic, classic cars?
Perhaps good cigars?
Maybe you think of a famous baseball player.
What about when somebody mentions North Korea?
You think about those missile tests,
maybe their notorious leader
or his good friend, Dennis Rodman.
(Laughter)
One thing that likely doesn't come to mind
textTarget: Do głowy raczej nam nie przychodzi

textSrc: is a vision of a country,
an open economy,
whose citizens have access to a wide range of affordable consumer products.
textTarget: którego mieszkańcy mają dostęp do wielu przystępnych cenowo produktów.

textSrc: I'm not here to argue how these countries got to where they are today.
textTarget: Nie będę wyjaśniał, jak te kraje  znalazły się w takim położeniu.

textSrc: I simply want to use them as an example of countries and citizens
textTarget: Używam ich jako przykładów  krajów i mieszkańców

textSrc: who have been affected, negatively affected,
by a trade policy that restricts imports
and protects local industries.
Recently we've heard a number of countries
talk about restricting imports
and protecting their local, domestic industries.
Now, this may sound fine in a sound bite,
but what it really is is protectionism.
We heard a lot about this during the 2016 presidential election.
textTarget: Słyszeliśmy o tym często w 2016 roku w czasie wyborów prezydenckich,

textSrc: We heard about it during the Brexit debates
and most recently during the French elections.
textTarget: a ostatnio przy okazji wyborów we Francji.

textSrc: In fact, it's been a really important topic
being talked about around the world,
and many aspiring political leaders
textTarget: Wiele osób aspirujących do roli lidera politycznego

textSrc: are running on platforms positioning protectionism as a good thing.
textTarget: proponuje program, według którego protekcjonizm jest dobry.

textSrc: Now, I could see why they think protectionism is good,
textTarget: Rozumiem, dlaczego myślą, że protekcjonizm jest dobry.

textSrc: because sometimes it seems like trade is unfair.
Some have blamed trade
for some of the problems we've been having here at home in the US.
textTarget: za problemy, które mamy tutaj, w Stanach.

textSrc: For years we've been hearing
about the loss of high-paying US manufacturing jobs.
textTarget: o utracie dobrze płatnych etatów w przemyśle USA.

textSrc: Many think that manufacturing is declining in the US
textTarget: Wielu uważa, że przemysł w USA zanika,

textSrc: because companies are moving their operations offshore
textTarget: bo firmy przenoszą pracę za granicę,

textSrc: to markets with lower-cost labor
textTarget: na rynki z tańszą siłą roboczą,

textSrc: like China, Mexico and Vietnam.
They also think trade agreements sometimes are unfair,
textTarget: Uważa się też, że umowy handlowe  czasami są niesprawiedliwe,

textSrc: like NAFTA
and the Trans-Pacific Partnership,
because these trade agreements allow companies
to reimport those cheaply produced goods back into the US
textTarget: importować tanio wyprodukowane towary z powrotem do USA

textSrc: and other countries from where the jobs were taken.
textTarget: lub do innych krajów, z których zabrano pracę.

textSrc: So it kind of feels like the exporters win
textTarget: Sprawia to wrażenie, że eksporterzy wygrywają,

textSrc: and the importers lose.
Now, the reality is
output in the manufacturing sector in the US
is actually growing,
but we are losing jobs.
We're losing lots of them.
In fact, from 2000 to 2010,
5.7 million manufacturing jobs were lost.
But they're not being lost for the reasons you might think.
textTarget: Ale z innych powodów, niż wam się zdaje.

textSrc: Mike Johnson in Toledo, Ohio
textTarget: Mike Johnson z Toledo w stanie Ohio

textSrc: didn't lose his jobs at the factory
to Miguel Sanchez in Monterrey, Mexico.
textTarget: na rzecz Miguela Sancheza z Monterrey w Meksyku.

textSrc: No.
Mike lost his job to a machine.
87 percent of lost manufacturing jobs
have been eliminated because we've made improvements
in our own productivity through automation.
So that means that one out of 10 lost manufacturing jobs
textTarget: 1 na 10 etatów zniknął z powodu przeniesienia firmy

textSrc: was due to offshoring.
Now, this is not just a US phenomenon.
textTarget: Dzieje się tak nie tylko w Stanach.

textSrc: No.
In fact, automation is spreading to every production line
textTarget: Automatyzacja rozszerza się  na wszystkie sektory przemysłu

textSrc: in every country around the world.
But look, I get it:
if you just lost your job
and then you read in the newspaper
that your old company just struck up a deal with China,
textTarget: że jego dawna firma podpisała umowę z Chinami,

textSrc: it's easy to think you were just replaced
in a one-for-one deal.
When I hear stories like this, I think that what people picture
textTarget: Słysząc takie historie, ludzie wyobrażają sobie chyba,

textSrc: is that trade happens between only two countries.
textTarget: że handel ogranicza się do dwóch krajów.

textSrc: Manufacturers in one country
produce products and they export them
to consumers in other countries,
and it feels like the manufacturing countries win
textTarget: Sprawia to wrażenie, że kraj produkujący wgrywa,

textSrc: and the importing countries lose.
Well, reality's a little bit different.
and I live and work in Mexico.
And I work in the middle
of a highly connected network of manufacturers
all collaborating from around the world
to produce many of the products we use today.
What I see
from my front-row seat in Mexico City
actually looks more like this.
And this is a more accurate depiction of what trade really looks like.
textTarget: Jest to bardziej precyzyjne  przedstawienie handlu.

textSrc: I've had the pleasure of being able to see
how many different products are manufactured,
from golf clubs to laptop computers
to internet servers, automobiles
and even airplanes.
And believe me, none of it happens in a straight line.
Let me give you an example.
A few months ago, I was touring the manufacturing plant
of a multinational aerospace company
in Querétaro, Mexico,
and the VP of logistics points out a completed tail assembly.
It turns out the tail assemblies are assembled from panels
that are manufactured in France,
and they're assembled in Mexico
using components imported from the US.
textTarget: z użyciem części sprowadzanych z USA.

textSrc: When those tail assemblies are done,
they're exported via truck to Canada
to their primary assembly plant
where they come together
with thousands of other parts,
like the wings and the seats
and the little shades over the little windows,
all coming in to become a part of a new airplane.
textTarget: Wszystko to staje się częścią nowego samolotu.

textSrc: Think about it.
These new airplanes,
before they even take their first flight,
they have more stamps in their passports
than Angelina Jolie.
Now, this approach to processing goes on all around the world
textTarget: Podejście to jest powszechne na świecie

textSrc: to manufacture many of the products
we use every day,
from skin cream to airplanes.
When you go home tonight, take a look in your house.
textTarget: Rozejrzyjcie się po powrocie do domu.

textSrc: You might be surprised to find a label that looks like this one:
textTarget: Może was zaskoczyć metka z takim napisem:

textSrc: "Manufactured in the USA from US and foreign parts."
textTarget: "Wyprodukowano w USA  z części krajowych i zagranicznych".

textSrc: Economist Michael Porter
described what's going on here best.
Many decades ago, he said that it's most beneficial for a country
textTarget: Wiele lat temu stwierdził, że najbardziej opłacalne dla kraju

textSrc: to focus on producing the products it can produce most efficiently
textTarget: jest wytwarzanie towarów, których produkcja jest efektywna,

textSrc: and trading for the rest.
So what he's talking about here is shared production,
and efficiency is the name of the game.
textTarget: a jedyne, co się liczy, to efektywność.

textSrc: You've probably seen an example of this
at home or at work.
Let's take a look at an example.
Think about how your house was built
or your kitchen renovated.
Typically, there's a general contractor
who is responsible for coordinating the efforts
of all the different contractors:
an architect to draw the plans,
an earth-moving company to dig the foundation,
a plumber, a carpenter and so on.
So why doesn't the general contractor
pick just one company
to do all the work,
like, say, the architect?
Because this is silly.
The general contractor selects experts
because it takes years
to learn and master
how to do each of the tasks it takes to build a house or renovate a kitchen,
textTarget: jak budowa domu czy  remont kuchni, trwa latami.

textSrc: some of them requiring special training.
Think about it:
Would you want your architect to install your toilet?
Of course not.
So let's apply this process to the corporate world.
Companies today focus on manufacturing
what they produce best and most efficiently,
textTarget: na produkcji towarów, które mogą zrobić najlepiej i najwydajniej,

textSrc: and they trade for everything else.
So this means they rely
textTarget: Oznacza to, że polegają na światowej

textSrc: on a global, interconnected, interdependent network of manufacturers
textTarget: powiązanej wzajemnie sieci zależności między wytwórcami,

textSrc: to produce these products.
In fact, that network is so interconnected
Let's take a look at the interconnected web
we saw a few moments ago,
and let's focus on just one strand
textTarget: i skoncentrujmy się na jednej linii

textSrc: between the US and Mexico.
The Wilson Institute says that shared production represents
textTarget: Instytut Wilsona twierdzi,  że podzielona produkcja stanowi

textSrc: 40 percent of the half a trillion dollars in trade between the US and Mexico.
textTarget: 40% z wartego pół biliona dolarów handlu między USA a Meksykiem.

textSrc: That's about 200 billion dollars,
or the same as the GDP for Portugal.
So let's just imagine
that the US decides to impose
a 20 percent border tax on all imports from Mexico.
OK, fine.
But do you think Mexico is just going to stand by and let that happen?
textTarget: Ale czy Meksyk będzie stał z boku i się przyglądał?

textSrc: No. No way.
So in retaliation, they impose a similar tax
on all goods being imported from the US,
and a little game of tit-for-tat ensues,
textTarget: i rozpocznie się gra wet za wet.

textSrc: and 20 percent -- just imagine that 20 percent duties
are added to every good, product, product component
textTarget: nałożone na wszystkie towary i części

textSrc: crossing back and forth across the border,
textTarget: krążące tam i z powrotem przez granicę

textSrc: and you could be looking at more than a 40 percent increase in duties,
textTarget: i mamy co najmniej 40% wzrost ceł

textSrc: or 80 billion dollars.
Now, don't kid yourself,
these costs are going to be passed along
to you and to me.
Now, let's think about what impact that might have on some of the products,
textTarget: Jaki to będzie miało wpływ  na niektóre produkty

textSrc: or the prices of the products, that we buy every day.
So if a 30 percent increase in duties were actually passed along,
we would be looking at some pretty important increases in prices.
A Lincoln MKZ would go from 37,000 dollars to 48,000.
textTarget: Cena Lincolna MKZ wzrośnie z 37 tysięcy dolarów do 48 tysięcy.

textSrc: And the price of a Sharp 60-inch HDTV
would go from 898 dollars to 1,167 dollars.
And the price of a 16-ounce jar of CVS skin moisturizer
would go from 13 dollars to 17 dollars.
Now, remember, this is only looking at one strand of the production chain
textTarget: Pamiętajcie, że patrzymy tylko  na jeden koniec linii z wykresu,

textSrc: between the US and Mexico,
so multiply this out across all of the strands.
textTarget: a trzeba pomnożyć tę wartość  przez wszystkie linie.

textSrc: The impact could be considerable.
Now, just think about this:
even if we were able to dismantle this network
textTarget: nawet jeśli dałoby się rozplątać tę sieć

textSrc: and produce products in just one country,
textTarget: i produkować towary w całości w jednym kraju,

textSrc: which by the way is easier said than done,
we would still only be saving or protecting
one out of 10 lost manufacturing jobs.
textTarget: jeden z dziesięciu utraconych  etatów przemysłowych.

textSrc: That's right, because remember,
most of those jobs, 87 percent,
were lost due to improvements in our own productivity.
And unfortunately, those jobs, they're gone for good.
textTarget: Niestety, te prace zniknęły na zawsze.

textSrc: So the real question is,
does it make sense for us to drive up prices
textTarget: czy ma sens napędzanie cen do momentu,

textSrc: to the point where many of us can't afford the basic goods we use every day
textTarget: w którym wielu nie będzie stać na produkty codziennego użytku,

textSrc: for the purpose of saving a job
that might be eliminated in a couple of years anyway?
textTarget: która pewnie i tak zniknie za kilka lat?

textSrc: The reality is that shared production
allows us to manufacture higher quality products
at lower costs.
It's that simple.
It allows us to get more
out of the limited resources and expertise we have
and at the same time benefit from lower prices.
textTarget: pozwalając jednocześnie korzystać z niskich cen.

textSrc: It's really important to remember
that for shared production to be effective,
textTarget: że aby podział produkcji był efektywny,

textSrc: it relies on efficient cross-border movement of raw materials,
textTarget: musi mieć miejsce wydajny  przepływ transgraniczny części,

textSrc: components and finished products.
So remember this:
the next time you're hearing somebody try to sell you on the idea
that protectionism is a good deal,
it's just not.
Thank you.
(Applause)
